locations.name: Valladolid
locations.description: Royal capital of Castile. Seat of the royal court and Juan II's primary residence.

locations.name: Medina del Campo
locations.description: Important Castilian town near Valladolid. Site of the crucial negotiation between Juan II and the Infantes de Aragón.

locations.name: Seville
locations.description: Major Castilian trade city on the Guadalquivir. Produces ~420,000 maravedís in quarterly customs revenues. Noble feuds between Guzmán and Ponce de León families.

locations.name: Toledo
locations.description: Religious center of Castile and seat of the Archbishop. Strategic importance for controlling central Castile.

locations.name: Granada
locations.description: Capital of the Nasrid Kingdom. Last Moorish stronghold in Iberia. Pays tribute to Castile but raids continue on the frontier.

locations.name: Santiago de Compostela
locations.description: Major Christian pilgrimage destination in northwest Castile. Site of the shrine of Saint James. Archbishop provided letters of recommendation for Juan II's journey to Rome.

locations.name: Rome
locations.description: Seat of the papacy and center of Western Christendom. Pope Martin V resides in the Vatican. Site of Juan II's dramatic act of renunciation and the granting of the crusade bull 'Inter Cetera Divinae Providentiae.'
sub_locations: Monastery of Santa Maria in Trastevere

locations.name: Florence
locations.description: Wealthy Italian city-state dominated by the Medici banking family. Cosimo de' Medici is de facto ruler. Site of Juan II's triumphant crusade speech in the Piazza della Signoria that drew 8,000-10,000 people and generated major financial and military pledges.

locations.name: Barcelona
locations.description: Major port city in the Crown of Aragon. Queen María manages the court in Alfonso V's absence. Site of Juan II's major crusade recruitment campaign — cathedral relic displays, 82,000 florins raised, 62 crusaders enrolled. The Consell Reial meets here and granted Aragonese support for the crusade.

locations.name: Jaen
locations.description: Frontier city in southern Castile, staging area for the eastern crusade army. Fortress city commanding the mountain passes into Granada. Supply depots established at Jaen and satellite positions at Ciudad Real, Ubeda, and Baeza.

locations.name: Alcala la Real
locations.description: Major Granadan frontier fortress on the road south from Jaen toward Granada. First target of the eastern crusade army. Garrison 800-1,000. Site of imminent decisive battle.

locations.name: Illora
locations.description: Granadan fortress 12 miles northwest of Alcala la Real, directly on the road to Granada city. Second target of the eastern crusade army's advance. Under siege by 15,000 Castilian troops with bombards under the Master of Calatrava. Siege delayed 2-3 weeks by guerrilla raids on supply lines.

locations.name: Vélez-Málaga
locations.description: Fortified coastal town east of Malaga taken by the western crusade army on April 2-6, 1431. First major coastal objective secured. Amphibious landing met minimal opposition. Citadel surrendered after 4 days of bombardment. Town population ~2,000 under Castilian military government. Strategic base for further coastal operations.

locations.name: Granada
locations.description: Capital of the Emirate of Granada. Site of the Alhambra palace. Sultan Muhammad IX's court. Juan II's army of 10,000 has marched to its gates on May 8-9, 1431 for a formal surrender demand. Sultan has 3,000-3,500 troops ready for a sortie. Counter-trap set by Castilians who intercepted the plan.

locations.name: Málaga
locations.description: Granada's second city and vital Mediterranean port. Population ~20,000. Strong walls, Alcazaba fortress on hill within the city, Gibralfaro castle above. Harbor with ships. Combined Castilian army of 30,270 with 5 bombards assembled on hills NE of the city on June 14, 1431.

locations.name: Marbella
locations.description: Coastal fortress west of Malaga. Taken July 26 after fierce resistance (180 dead, 240 wounded). Part of western coastal advance.

locations.name: Estepona
locations.description: Coastal fortress further west, taken August 11 (85 dead, 120 wounded). Western army continuing advance toward Gibraltar.

locations.name: Ronda
locations.description: One of Granada's strongest fortresses. Built on limestone plateau split by Tajo gorge (300 feet deep). Northern approach only viable route for artillery. Surrendered peacefully October 5, 1431 after negotiation. Population ~8,000. Agricultural lands redistributed to Castilian nobles, 5% revenue tax, one mosque preserved.

locations.name: Gaucín
locations.description: Fortified hilltop village west of Ronda. Secondary raider base. Surrendered after bombard fire October 8, 1431. 70 fighters departed, 130 people remained.

locations.name: Antequera
locations.description: Mid-sized frontier town between Ronda and Córdoba. Used as waypoint during Juan's journey to Toledo.

locations.name: Córdoba
locations.description: Major Castilian city on the Guadalquivir River. Famous Roman bridge with 16 arches. Juan detoured through here due to flooded river crossing.

locations.name: Niebla
locations.description: Seat of the Count of Niebla, now in open rebellion against the crown. Target for bombard siege in spring 1432.
